As expected, 351i, 408i, and Y805S all failed to sustain the mitotic growth of the yeast strain in contrast to wild-type human topoisomerase IIα (Fig. 1B). 351i, 408i, and Y805S Do Not Induce Dominant Sensitivity toward ICRF-193 in Yeast—ICRF-193 is a topoisomerase II-directed drug, which stabilizes topoisomerase II in its closed clamp form (8Roca J. Ishida R. Berger J.M. Andoh T. Wang J.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1994; 91: 1781-1785Crossref PubMed Scopus (338) Google Scholar), and until recently, it was anticipated that the cytotoxicity of ICRF compounds simply was attributed to an inhibition of the essential topoisomerase II activity. However, the expression of wild-type human topoisomerase IIα in yeast cells has been demonstrated to confer dominant sensitivity to ICRF, suggesting that the drug acts as a topoisomerase II poison (15van Hille B. Hill B.T. Cancer Chemother. Pharmacol. 1998; 42: 345-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). In contrast, the expression of a cleavage-deficient human topoisomerase II enzyme does not alter the yeast sensitivity to ICRF-193, even though this enzyme still has a functional N-terminal clamp (11Jensen L.H. Nitiss K.C. Rose A. Dong J. Zhou J. Hu T. Osheroff N. Jensen P.B. Sehested M. Nitiss J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 2137-2146Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). This indicates that, besides clamp closure, either DNA cleavage or the strand passage activity of topoisomerase II is required for ICRF-193 to exert its poisoning effect. To test which of the enzymatic capabilities of human topoisomerase IIα are important for the enzyme to cause dominant sensitivity to ICRF-193 in yeast cells, we expressed 351i, 408i, Y805S, or wild-type human topoisomerase IIα in the yeast strain Y12409. As a control, the cells were transformed with the empty vector pRS315. To verify the expression of the human topoisomerase IIα enzymes, the Western blot analysis of cell lysates from all of the yeast transformants was carried out using an antibody specific to human topoisomerase IIα. As seen in Fig. 2A, both mutant and wild-type enzymes were expressed in the Y12409 yeast cells, although Y805S was expressed consistently at a lower level. To assess the cytotoxicity of ICRF-193 in the different transformants, the yeast cells were incubated either in the absence or presence of 85 μm ICRF-193. Aliquots were removed after 4 and 8 h and plated to determine cell survival after proper dilution. The results confirmed that the expression of wild-type human topoisomerase IIα in yeast confers sensitivity to ICRF-193, because the drug induced severe cell killing (Fig. 2B). Furthermore, the cleavage-deficient enzyme did not confer ICRF sensitivity as expected (11Jensen L.H. Nitiss K.C. Rose A. Dong J. Zhou J. Hu T. Osheroff N. Jensen P.B. Sehested M. Nitiss J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 2137-2146Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar). Yeast cells expressing the clamp-deficient 408i enzyme displayed little or no sensitivity to ICRF-193, showing that the cleavage activity is insufficient to induce ICRF cytotoxicity. The strand passage-deficient human topoisomerase IIα enzyme, 351i, which retains both clamp closure and DNA cleavage activity also induced little or no ICRF cytotoxicity (Fig. 2B). Thus, neither DNA cleavage, clamp closure, nor both activities together are sufficient for ICRF-193 to mediate cell killing via topoisomerase II. Our results strongly suggest that strand transport, which is blocked in all three mutant enzymes, is an absolute requirement for ICRF-mediated cell killing. ICRF-193 Induces Stable Clamp Formation in Wild-type Topoisomerase IIα, 351i, and Y805S but Not in 408i—To investigate whether the inability of ICRF-193 to cause cytotoxicity in yeast cells expressing 351i, 408i, or Y805S was because of a lack of drug-mediated clamp stabilization with these enzymes, we tested the ability of ICRF-193 to stabilize the closed clamp conformation in the mutant topoisomerase IIα enzymes in vitro. For this purpose, the different enzymes fused to a hexahistidine tail at the C-terminal end were overexpressed in a yeast top1 null strain and purified as described under “Experimental Procedures.” To test the effect of ICRF-193 in vitro, wild-type and mutant enzymes were preincubated with supercoiled plasmid DNA and ATP before the addition of ICRF-193. The reactions were stopped by adding high concentrations of salt, and the samples were subjected to a clamp-closing analysis modified from Bjergbaek et al. (24Bjergbaek L. Kingma P. Nielsen I.S. Wang Y. Westergaard O. Osheroff N. Andersen A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 13041-13048Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). In contrast to 408i, the wild-type enzyme as well as 351i and Y805S caught the circular plasmid DNA in the presence of ATP and ICRF-193 (Fig. 3), in accordance with the previously reported clamp-closing capabilities of the enzymes (11Jensen L.H. Nitiss K.C. Rose A. Dong J. Zhou J. Hu T. Osheroff N. Jensen P.B. Sehested M. Nitiss J.L. J. Biol. Thus, the inability of ICRF-193 to cause cytotoxicity in vivo in yeast cells expressing 351i and Y805S does not correlate with an inability of ICRF-193 to stabilize the closed clamp complex in 351i and Y805S. The results further revealed that the general clamp-closing defect of 408i also abolishes the ability of ICRF-193 to induce a salt-stable topological complex between this enzyme and DNA. Also, the results confirm that 351i, 408i, and Y805S are unable to perform the relaxation of supercoiled DNA, because the occurrence of relaxed DNA is only seen when clamp closure is performed in the presence of wild-type topoisomerase IIα. m-AMSA but Not ICRF-193 Increases the DNA Cleavage Level Obtained with 351i, 408i, and the Wild-type Topoisomerase IIα Enzyme—Traditional topoisomerase II poisons, including m-AMSA, increase the concentration of topoisomerase II-mediated DNA breaks (reviewed by Fortune and Osheroff (7Fortune J.M. Osheroff N. Prog. Nucleic Acids Res. Mol. Biol. 2000; 64: 221-253Crossref PubMed Google Scholar)). Some studies also have reported an ICRF-induced increase in topoisomerase II-mediated DNA cleavage complex formation (17Huang K.C. Gao H. Yamasaki E.F. Grabowski D.R. Liu S. Shen L.L. Chan K.K. Ganapathi R. Snapka R.M. J. Biol. Chem. 2001; 276: 44488-44494Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (79) Google Scholar). To test whether the different mutant enzymes as well as wild-type human topoisomerase IIα can respond to m-AMSA and ICRF-193 with increased enzyme-DNA cleavage complex formation, DNA cleavage reactions were performed in the absence or presence of 100 μm m-AMSA or 85 μm ICRF-193 using a 3′-end-labeled DNA substrate. Reactions were stopped with SDS and were subjected to electrophoresis in an 8% SDS gel. Cleavage complexes were identified because of the covalent linkage of labeled DNA after DNA cleavage. As seen in Fig. 4A, upper panel, m-AMSA dramatically increases the DNA cleavage level obtained with the wild-type enzyme as well as that obtained with 351i and 408i. Y805S is unable to cleave DNA to a detectable level even in the presence of drug. Thus, m-AMSA is able to mediate its stimulatory effect on the three cleavage-competent enzymes irrespective of their overall catalytic activity. In contrast, the induction in DNA cleavage complex formation obtained with ICRF-193 is insignificant with all of the enzymes under the reaction condition used in this study (Fig. 4A, lower panel). To investigate whether ICRF-193 stimulates topoisomerase II-mediated DNA cleavage on plasmid DNA containing multiple DNA cleavage sites, topoisomerase II was incubated with circular plasmid DNA in the presence of 50 μm ICRF-193, 50 μm m-AMSA, or 0.5% Me2SO. Reactions were stopped by the addition of SDS to 1%, and topoisomerase II-mediated double strand cleavage was revealed as linearization of the plasmid DNA after proteinase K digestion (Fig. 4B, upper panel). As expected, the DNA cleavage activity of wild-type human topoisomerase IIα as well as that of 351i and 408i is stimulated by m-AMSA. However, even using a substrate containing multiple topoisomerase II recognition sites, neither of the enzymes shows an increased DNA cleavage level in the presence of ICRF-193 under the present conditions (Fig. 4B, lower panel). The DNA Cleavage-competent Enzymes, 351i and 408i, Both Confer Sensitivity to m-AMSA in Vivo—The cytotoxic effect of m-AMSA is believed to result directly from an increase in the cellular level of DNA double strand breaks, but it has not been investigated whether topoisomerase activity is in fact required for m-AMSA to exert its effect in vivo. To test this possibility, we have compared the m-AMSA sensitivity of yeast cells expressing 351i or 408i, which are able to cleave DNA in vitro but unable to perform strand passage, to the sensitivity of cells expressing either Y805S, which is incapable of both DNA cleavage and strand passage, or the wild-type enzyme, which is capable of both activities. Yeast cells transformed with the empty vector, pRS315, were used to reveal the sensitivity of the yeast strain expressing only yeast topoisomerase II. The cytotoxicity of m-AMSA in the different transformants was assessed by incubating yeast cells either in the absence or presence of 100 μm m-AMSA. Aliquots were removed after 4 and 8 h and plated to determine cell survival after proper dilution. The results show that yeast cells expressing either one of the cleavage-competent enzymes, 351i or 408i, or the wild-type enzyme are sensitive to m-AMSA, whereas cells expressing the cleavage-deficient Y805S enzyme are as insensitive as those harboring the empty vector (Fig. 5). These observations demonstrated that the cytotoxicity of m-AMSA is independent of topoisomerase II activity and solely results from the formation of topoisomerase II-DNA cleavage complexes. Furthermore, our data revealed that 351i and 408i, besides being expressed, are capable of mediating DNA cleavage in the yeast cells, in agreement with their in vitro abilities (19Oestergaard V.H. Giangiacomo L. Bjergbaek L. Knudsen B.R. Andersen A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 28093-28099Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar, 20Oestergaard V.H. Bjergbaek L. Skouboe C. Giangiacomo L. Knudsen B.R. Andersen A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 1684-1691Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). Recently, several studies have focused on the topoisomerase II-directed ICRF compounds, and accumulating evidence that these drugs work as a type of topoisomerase II poison has been presented (10Kobayashi M. Adachi N. Aratani Y. Kikuchi A. Koyama H. Cancer Lett. 2001; 166: 71-77Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 11Jensen L.H. Nitiss K.C. Rose A. Dong J. Zhou J. Hu T. Osheroff N. Jensen P.B. Sehested M. Nitiss J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 2137-2146Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 12Adachi N. Suzuki H. Iiizumi S. Koyama H. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 35897-35902Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar, 13Hasinoff B.B. Kuschak T.I. Creighton A.M. Fattman C.L. Allan W.P. Thampatty P. Yalowich J.C. Biochem. Pharmacol. 1997; 53: 1843-1853Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 14van Hille B. Clerc X. Creighton A.M. Hill B.T. Br. J. Cancer. 1999; 81: 800-807Crossref PubMed Scopus (12) Google Scholar, 15van Hille B. Hill B.T. Cancer Chemother. Pharmacol. 1998; 42: 345-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar). However, it is presently not clear how the ICRF compounds exert their poisoning action. In this study, we have taken advantage of three biochemically well characterized human topoisomerase IIα enzymes to determine the steps in the catalytic cycle of human topoisomerase IIα required for the enzyme to cause sensitivity to ICRF-193 in yeast cells. In agreement with previous findings (11Jensen L.H. Nitiss K.C. Rose A. Dong J. Zhou J. Hu T. Osheroff N. Jensen P.B. Sehested M. Nitiss J.L. J. Biol. Chem. 2000; 275: 2137-2146Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (88) Google Scholar, 15van Hille B. Hill B.T. Cancer Chemother. Pharmacol. 1998; 42: 345-356Crossref PubMed Scopus (28) Google Scholar), we have shown that yeast cells expressing wild-type human topoisomerase IIα in trans are hypersensitive to ICRF-193. In contrast, the expression of neither one of the strand passage-deficient human topoisomerase IIα enzymes, 351i, 408i, and Y805S, conferred sensitivity to ICRF-193 in yeast cells, although both 351i and Y805S were found to undergo stable closure of the N-terminal clamp in the presence of ATP and ICRF-193 in vitro. The lack of sensitivity in cells expressing 408i can be explained by the inability of the enzyme to perform clamp closure. Y805S would also be expected to be unable to cause ICRF sensitivity if topoisomerase II-mediated DNA cleavage was a requirement for ICRF cytotoxicity. However, the fact that 351i, capable of both clamp closure and DNA cleavage, still does not confer sensitivity to ICRF-193 demonstrates that neither the DNA cleavage activity of topoisomerase II nor the ability of the drug to induce stable clamp closure can be the main cause of cell killing by ICRF-193. Rather, the strand transport activity of topoisomerase II, which is the only activity lacking in all of the mutant enzymes, seems to be necessary for the cell-killing mechanism of ICRF-193. We also used the yeast system to investigate the cell-killing mechanism of a traditional topoisomerase II poison, m-AMSA. The cleavage-competent topoisomerase IIα enzymes, wild type, 351i, and 408i, were all found to cause hypersensitivity to m-AMSA when expressed in yeast, in agreement with their in vitro capability to respond to m-AMSA with increased levels of DNA cleavage complex formation. In contrast, the expression of the cleavage-deficient Y805S did not elevate the m-AMSA sensitivity of the yeast cells. This strongly suggests that m-AMSA solely works via the DNA cleavage ability of topoisomerase II and that the m-AMSA-induced increase seen in cleavage complex formation in vitro directly reflects the cell-killing mechanism of m-AMSA. The ability of 351i and 408i to cause sensitivity to m-AMSA in yeast further confirms that these enzymes are present in the yeast nucleus and have retained their ability to cleave DNA, in agreement with the previous in vitro characterizations (19Oestergaard V.H. Giangiacomo L. Bjergbaek L. Knudsen B.R. Andersen A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 28093-28099Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (8) Google Scholar, 20Oestergaard V.H. Bjergbaek L. Skouboe C. Giangiacomo L. Knudsen B.R. Andersen A.H. J. Biol. Chem. 2004; 279: 1684-1691Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (22) Google Scholar). The fact that ICRF cytotoxicity depends on the strand passage reaction of topoisomerase II strongly indicates that the drug traps a cellular topoisomerase II reaction intermediate that is toxic to the cell. The inability of 351i to create this toxic intermediate suggests that it arises during the strand passage reaction or at a later step in the catalytic cycle of topoisomerase II. The newly published structure of an N-terminal fragment of yeast topoisomerase II shows that the cavity formed by the N-terminal clamp of eukaryotic topoisomerase II is considerably smaller than that of DNA gyrase and thus cannot hold a T-segment after the clamp has been closed (6Classen S. Olland S. Berger J.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 10629-10634Crossref PubMed Scopus (215) Google Scholar). Consequently, the strand passage-deficient 351i and Y805S enzymes only interact with one DNA segment, the G-segment, once the clamp has been stably closed by the binding of ICRF-193 to the N-terminal domain. This provides an obvious explanation for the lack of ICRF sensitivity displayed by the yeast cells expressing these mutant enzymes compared with those expressing the wild-type human topoisomerase IIα, namely the toxic intermediate being topoisomerase II stably bound to two DNA segments. The lack of cytotoxicity observed with 351i and Y805S can be explained by a model predicting that topoisomerase II clamped around one DNA segment can slide freely on DNA and therefore does not interfere with DNA-tracking machineries during transcription and replication. In contrast, the complex formed between the wild-type topoisomerase II and two DNA segments may be more restricted in its movements along DNA and in this way inhibits both the transcription and replication processes. In support of this model, it has been shown that ICRF-193 inhibits transcription and it has been suggested that collision with the transcription machinery is responsible for the efficient degradation of topoisomerase IIβ that occurs upon ICRF treatment of human cell cultures (25Xiao H. Mao Y. Desai S.D. Zhou N. Ting C.Y. Hwang J. Liu L.F. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 2003; 100: 3239-3244Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). The elevated sensitivity to ICRF displayed by chicken cells deficient in non-homologous end joining indicates that DNA strand breaks do occur upon ICRF treatment (12Adachi N. Suzuki H. Iiizumi S. Koyama H. J. Biol. Chem. 2003; 278: 35897-35902Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar). Along with the presented model, these breaks could occur upon collision of the complex of topoisomerase II bound to two DNA segments with the replication or transcription machinery. Alternatively, the DNA breaks could result from intolerable strain in the DNA created by the topoisomerase II complex. In conclusion, we have found that ICRF-193 and m-AMSA work by distinct mechanisms where ICRF-193 depends on the strand passage activity of topoisomerase II, most probably the result of the simultaneous interaction of the enzyme with two DNA segments. This is different from m-AMSA that works directly via the DNA cleavage ability of topoisomerase II.

The 12/23 rule is a critical step for regulation of V(D)J recombination. To date, only the RAG proteins and high mobility group protein 1 or 2 have been implicated in 12/23 regulation. Through protein fractionation and biochemical experiments, we find that Ku70/Ku80 and DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit (DNA-PKcs) modulate RAG-mediated cleavage. Modulation of cleavage by Ku70/80 and DNA-PKcs results in preferential inhibition of 12/12 and 23/23 DNA cleavage, thus increasing 12/23 rule specificity. This observation indicates that DNA repair factors, Ku70/80 and DNA-PKcs, might be present upstream of the DNA cleavage events and not recruited downstream as is currently thought, assigning new nonrepair functions to the DNA-dependent protein kinase. The 12/23 rule is a critical step for regulation of V(D)J recombination. To date, only the RAG proteins and high mobility group protein 1 or 2 have been implicated in 12/23 regulation. Through protein fractionation and biochemical experiments, we find that Ku70/Ku80 and DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit (DNA-PKcs) modulate RAG-mediated cleavage. Modulation of cleavage by Ku70/80 and DNA-PKcs results in preferential inhibition of 12/12 and 23/23 DNA cleavage, thus increasing 12/23 rule specificity. This observation indicates that DNA repair factors, Ku70/80 and DNA-PKcs, might be present upstream of the DNA cleavage events and not recruited downstream as is currently thought, assigning new nonrepair functions to the DNA-dependent protein kinase. V(D)J recombination allows for rearrangement of antigen receptor gene variable (V), diversity (D), and joining (J) segments, resulting in a diverse array of antigen receptors. The reaction occurs in B and T cells and requires the recombinase activity of the lymphoid-specific RAG1 and RAG2 (1Oettinger M.A. Schatz D.G. Gorka C. Baltimore D. Science. 1990; 248: 1517-1523Crossref PubMed Scopus (1124) Google Scholar, 2Schatz D.G. Oettinger M.A. Baltimore D. Cell. 1989; 59: 1035-1048Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (950) Google Scholar). RAG1/2 are directed to the correct sites of recombination by recombination signal sequences (RSSs), 1The abbreviations used are: RSS, recombination signal sequence; NHEJ, nonhomologous end-joining; HMGB1 and -2, high mobility group protein 1 and 2, respectively; WCE, whole cell extract; GST, glutathione S-transferase; Trx, thioredoxin; HA, hemagglutinin; SE, signal end; DNA-PK, DNA-dependent protein kinase; DNA-PKcs, DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit.1The abbreviations used are: RSS, recombination signal sequence; NHEJ, nonhomologous end-joining; HMGB1 and -2, high mobility group protein 1 and 2, respectively; WCE, whole cell extract; GST, glutathione S-transferase; Trx, thioredoxin; HA, hemagglutinin; SE, signal end; DNA-PK, DNA-dependent protein kinase; DNA-PKcs, DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit. each consisting of a conserved nonamer and heptamer element, separated by a less conserved spacer of 12 (12RSS) or 23 (23RSS) nucleotides (3Gellert M. Adv. Immunol. 1997; 64: 39-64Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). The recombination reaction can be divided into two steps. First, RAGs bind and cleave at the heptamer/coding borders of one 12RSS and one 23RSS, generating hairpin coding ends and blunt 5′-phosphorylated signal ends (4Fugmann S.D. Lee A.I. Shockett P.E. Villey I.J. Schatz D.G. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2000; 18: 495-527Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar). Second, DNA breaks are repaired, with hairpin coding ends being opened, processed, and ligated to form an imprecise coding joint, and signal ends are precisely ligated to form a signal joint (4Fugmann S.D. Lee A.I. Shockett P.E. Villey I.J. Schatz D.G. Annu. Rev. Immunol. 2000; 18: 495-527Crossref PubMed Scopus (496) Google Scholar). In vivo and in vitro experiments have shown that the processing-repair step involves the participation of lymphoid-specific terminal deoxynucleotidyl transferases (TdTS and TdTL) (5Thai T.H. Purugganan M.M. Roth D.B. Kearney J.F. Nat. Immunol. 2002; 3: 457-462Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar), the ubiquitous nonhomologous end-joining (NHEJ) factors, including Ku70, Ku80, DNA-dependent protein kinase catalytic subunit (DNA-PKcs), XRCC4, DNA ligase IV, Artemis (for a review, see Refs. 6Schlissel M.S. Nat. Rev. Immunol. 2003; 3: 890-899Crossref PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar and 7Lees-Miller S.P. Meek K. Biochimie (Paris). 2003; 85: 1161-1173Crossref PubMed Scopus (299) Google Scholar), and DNA polymerase μ (8Bertocci B. De Smet A. Berek C. Weill J.C. Reynaud C.A. Immunity. 2003; 19: 203-211Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar). How all of these factors are specifically recruited and coordinately assembled during V(D)J recombination is largely unknown (for further discussion see Ref. 9Mansilla-Soto J. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 2003; 197: 543-547Crossref PubMed Scopus (20) Google Scholar). However, it has been proposed that they are recruited through interactions of Ku70/80 with RAG-generated ends (10Jung D. Alt F.W. Cell. 2004; 116: 299-311Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (272) Google Scholar, 11Lieber M.R. Ma Y. Pannicke U. Schwarz K. Nat. Rev. Mol. Cell. Biol. 2003; 4: 712-720Crossref PubMed Scopus (780) Google Scholar, 12Gellert M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 2002; 71: 101-132Crossref PubMed Scopus (603) Google Scholar). Recombination must be correctly targeted, both spatially and temporally. One critical level of regulation is that a 12RSS and 23RSS pairing is highly preferred for recombination. This preference, termed the 12/23 rule, operates at the cleavage step of the reaction in vivo and in vitro (13Hiom K. Gellert M. Mol. Cell. 1998; 1: 1011-1019Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (205) Google Scholar, 14Steen S.B. Gomelsky L. Roth D.B. Leu T.M. Schatz D.G. Nature. 1996; 380: 85-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). RAG1/2 were first shown to establish the 12/23 rule in vitro (17van Gent D.C. Ramsden D.A. Gellert M. Cell. 1996; 85: 107-113Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (246) Google Scholar), with a 3-4-fold preference for a 12/23 substrate. We and others have shown that high mobility group protein 1 or 2 (HMGB1 or HMGB2) stimulates RAG-mediated cleavage (18van Gent D.C. Hiom K. Paull T.T. Gellert M. EMBO J. 1997; 16: 2665-2670Crossref PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar, 19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Using a cis-RSS cleavage assay containing RAGs, we reported that additional ubiquitous factors present in whole cell extract (WCE) enhance the 12/23 rule (19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 2025-2032Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). We have fractionated and characterized this extract and here demonstrate that DNA-PKcs and Ku70/Ku80 play a role in 12/23-regulated cleavage. Since the 12/23 rule is set at the cleavage step, this finding implicates DNA-PKcs and Ku70/Ku80 as components of the precleavage complex upstream of DNA repair. The mammalian expression vectors for GST-core RAG1 and GST-core RAG2 have been described (34Cortes P. Weis-Garcia F. Misulovin Z. Nussenzweig A. Lai J.S. Li G. Nussenzweig M.C. Baltimore D. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1996; 93: 14008-14013Crossref PubMed Scopus (39) Google Scholar). Plasmids pEF-FT-RAG1 and pEFHT-RAG2 encode thioredoxin (Trx) fusions to core RAG1 (residues 380-1040) or core RAG2 (residues 1-383), tagged at the N terminus with a FLAG (RAG1) or an HA (RAG2) epitope. A. 1993; 90: 8392-8396Crossref PubMed Scopus (2275) Google Scholar). RAGs—GST-RAG proteins were copurified, as described (19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 2025-2032Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). FLAG-Trx-RAG1·HA-Trx-RAG2 complex was purified by incubating the cell lysate with anti-FLAG M2-agarose affinity gel (Sigma); after subsequent washes, the fusion proteins were eluted at 4 °C in elution buffer consisting of 25 mm Tris-HCl (pH 8.0, 4 °C), 200 mm NaCl, 20% glycerol, and 200 μg/ml FLAG peptide (Sigma). Protein preparations were kept at -80 °C. Concentrations of GST-RAG1 and GST-RAG2 were determined to be 100 and 200 ng/μl, respectively. For FLAG-Trx-RAG and HA-Trx-RAG2, the concentrations were 100 and 50 ng/μl, respectively. HMGB1—Cells from a 1-liter bacterial (BL21) culture were resuspended in 30 ml of lysis buffer (20 mm Tris·HCl, pH 7.5, 200 mm NaCl, 1.0% Nonidet P-40, and protease inhibitors) and then successively treated with lysozyme (50 μg/ml) and DNase I (200 μg/ml and 5 mm MgCl2) for 1-2 h at 4 °C. The lysed mixture was centrifuged at 16,000 rpm for 30 min to collect the supernatant. The supernatant was passed through a 2-ml Ni2+-nitrilotriacetic acid column, washed extensively with the wash buffer (50 mm NaH2PO4, pH 8.0, 0.5 m NaCl, 5 mmβ-mercaptoethanol, 0.5% Tween 20, 10 mm imidazole, and 10% glycerol), and then the protein was eluted with 350 mm imidazole in wash buffer. The sample was dialyzed in buffer B (50 mm NaH2PO4, pH 8.0, 0.1 m NaCl, 5 mm β-mercaptoethanol, and 10% glycerol) and loaded on a 20-ml DEAE column. Elution was made with a 0.1-1.0 m KCl gradient, and the fractions containing HMGB1 (it was eluted near 220 mm KCl) was pooled together and dialyzed against buffer B. The dialyzed sample was loaded on a 5-ml MonoQ column, and the protein was eluted with a 0.1-0.5 m KCl gradient. His6-HMGB1 was eluted between 200 and 250 mm KCl. The fractions containing HMGB1 were pooled together and dialyzed against 25 mm Tris·HCl, pH 7.5, 150 mm NaCl, 2 mm dithiothreitol, and 10% glycerol. 293T cells were grown in spinner culture in Joklik's minimal essential medium (Sigma), and 100 liters of suspension cells were grown and harvested (National Cell Culture Center, Minneapolis, MN). Whole cell extracts were prepared as described (16Eastman Q.M. Leu T.M. Schatz D.G. Nature. 1996; 380: 85-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar, 19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 2025-2032Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). Column fractions were analyzed by two cleavage assays: one assaying only for cleavage enhancing activity, to locate active peaks, and the other utilizing the positive peak in combination with the S300 activity (regulated cleavage assay). The 293T WCE was loaded onto a High Q column equilibrated with BC100 (20 mm Tris-Cl pH 7.9, 0.2 mm EDTA, 20% glycerol, 100 mm KCl, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 1 mm dithiothreitol). The flow-through (possessing the 12/23 enforcing activity) was loaded onto a High S column equilibrated with BH100 (20 mm HEPES, pH 7.9, 1 mm MgCl2, 0.1 mm EDTA, 20% glycerol, 100 mm KCl, 1 mm phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, and 1 mm dithiothreitol). The column was step-eluted at 300, 600, and 1000 mm KCl. The regulatory activity separated into cleavage-enhancing and cleavage-inhibitory activities at this point. For cleavage-enhancing activity, see the Supplementary Material. For cleavage-inhibitory activity, the 300 mm elution from the High S column was further fractionated into several columns, but the inhibitory activity was lost. Using human placenta or HeLa cells as a source, Ku70/Ku80 heterodimer and DNA-PKcs were separately purified as previously described (37Chan D.W. Mody C.H. Ting N.S. Lees-Miller S.P. Biochem. Cell Biol. 1996; 74: 67-73Crossref PubMed Scopus (83) Google Scholar). End-labeled linear double stranded cis-cleavage substrates were obtained by EcoRI digestion of the pDS substrates, liberating a DNA fragment containing the respective RSS pair. 250 ng of the cleavage substrate was then radioactively end-labeled with exo- Klenow enzyme and [α-32P]dATP and [α-32P]TTP. The labeled substrates were gel-purified, ethanol-precipitated, and resuspended in 5 mm Tris-Cl (pH 7.9). Body-labeled linear double-stranded cis-cleavage substrates were obtained by PCR using the pJH290 DNAs, RA2, and RA14 primers and [α-32P]dCTP. Radioactive PCR products were first purified by column (Qiagen) and further purified by gel extraction; DNA was quantified by agarose gel-ethidium bromide staining. Assays Containing Linear DNA—Cleavage reaction conditions were as previously described (16Eastman Q.M. Leu T.M. Schatz D.G. Nature. 1996; 380: 85-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar, 19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 2025-2032Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar), except that 5 mm MgAc2 was used in the assay (50 μl). For protein purification experiments, assays contained combinations of 100 ng of GST-RAG1 (19 nm), 200 ng of GSTRAG2 (58 nm), column pools containing the cleavage enhancing and cleavage inhibitory activities, and 1.5 μg of HMGB1 (1.2 μm) when required. Reconstitution experiments using GST-RAGs contained the above proteins plus 10-100 ng of Ku70/Ku80 (1.3-13 nm) and 10-100 ng of DNA-PKcs (0.4-4 nm). Reconstitution experiments using Trx-RAGs contained 100 ng of FLAG-Trx-RAG1 (23 nm), 50 ng of HA-Trx-RAG2 (18 nm), 50-500 ng of HMGB1 (40-400 nm), 100-400 ng of Ku70/Ku80 (13-52 nm), and 100-400 ng of DNA-PKcs (4-16 nm). After sample processing, gel electrophoresis, and gel drying, DNA cleavage products were visualized using a Storm PhosphorImager (Amersham Biosciences) and quantified using ImageQuant software (Amersham Biosciences). For body-labeled linear substrates, signal end (SE) product was used as a direct parameter to quantify cleavage activity. To properly compare between different linear DNA substrates, the levels of SE product were expressed as a percentage of the radioactivity of its corresponding DNA substrate. -Fold preference of 12/23 substrate was determined by comparing the percentages of SE products between 12/23 and 12/12 or 23/23 substrate-containing reactions. Assays Containing Plasmid DNA—Cleavage reactions were carried out with 1 μg (6.7 nm) of pDS plasmids (12/23, 12/12, or 23/23) and the same amount of proteins as above, except that 400 ng of FLAG-Trx-RAG1 (92 nm) and 200 ng of HA-Trx-RAG2 (72 nm) were used. After a 1.5-h incubation, samples were processed exactly as described above, except that precipitated DNA was resuspended in 0.1× TE buffer and digested with the single cutting enzyme NcoI (10 units) for 3 h. After digestion, DNA was fractionated on a native 1.1% agarose gel, transferred to nylon membranes, UV-cross-linked, and probed with a radiolabeled probe obtained by PCR using the RA2 and RA14 primers and pJH290 12/23 as template. Data were then visualized and quantified as described. SE product was used as a direct parameter to compare between different substrates. The monoclonal antibody 162 (NeoMarkers), recognizing the Ku70/Ku80 native heterodimer, or an isotype-matched control anti-keratin monoclonal antibody LHK6B (NeoMarkers) was cross-linked to Protein A-Sepharose. 200 μl of S300 regulatory fraction was incubated with 10 μl of cross-linked anti-Ku or anti-keratin beads for 1 h at 4 °C. Beads were pelleted by centrifugation, and supernatants were transferred to a second microcentrifuge tube and incubated again with 10 μl of anti-Ku or anti-keratin beads. This process was repeated four times. Protein samples were resolved on a 4-20% SDS-PAGE gel and transferred to polyvinylidene difluoride membrane. Chicken anti-HMGB2 antibody was used for HMGB proteins. For Ku70/Ku80 Western blots, monoclonals N3H10 and 111 were used (Neomarkers). The antibody 18-2 (Neomarkers) was used to detect DNA-PKcs. Identification of a 12/23 Rule Enforcing Activity—Our previous work demonstrated that RAG1 and RAG2 complemented with 293T WCE show strict 12/23 regulation in vitro (19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 2025-2032Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). To facilitate the characterization of the regulatory activity found in the 293T WCE, we used cis-cleavage substrates (19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 2025-2032Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar) equally labeled at both ends (Fig. 1A). Cleavage at both RSSs yields 90- and 180-base pair radiolabeled DNA fragments from the 12/23, 12/12, and 23/23 substrates; single RSS cleavage events produce fragments of ∼380 or 470 base pairs (Fig. 1A). The 12/23 rule predicts that only coupled cleavage products (cleavage at both RSSs) from the 12/23 substrate should be formed. Copurified GST-core-RAG1 and GST-core-RAG2 (RAG1/2) were able to cleave all substrates (Fig. 1B, lanes 1 and 2). Purified recombinant HMGB1 added to the reaction preferentially enhanced RAG-mediated cleavage of substrates possessing a 23RSS (Fig. 1B, lanes 5 and 6). Since the combination of RAG1/2 and HMGB1 still produced high levels of cleavage of 12/12 and 23/23 substrates, this protein combination was evidently not sufficient to enforce the 12/23 rule (Fig. 1B, lanes 5 and 6). In contrast, the addition of 293T WCE to the reaction gave only coupled cleavage products from the 12/23 substrate and suppressed cleavage of 12/12 and 23/23 substrates in this system (Fig. 1B, lanes 3 and 4). Thus, 293T WCE possesses an activity that promotes 12/23-regulated cleavage, as previously described (19Sawchuk D.J. Weis-Garcia F. Malik S. Besmer E. Bustin M. Nussenzweig M.C. Cortes P. J. Exp. Med. 1997; 185: 2025-2032Crossref PubMed Scopus (119) Google Scholar). To identify the factors involved, we generated WCE from a 100-liter 293T cell culture. We then fractionated the WCE using a High Q column as a negative chromatography step. The flow-through from this column was applied to a High S column at 100 mm KCl and step-eluted at 300, 600, and 1000 mm KCl. This resolved two regulatory activities (Fig. 1C, lanes 2 and 3). The 300 mm High S fraction (S300) was inhibitory, decreasing RAG-mediated cleavage of all substrates (Fig. 1C, lane 2). In contrast, the 600 mm High S fraction (S600) had a cleavage-enhancing activity similar to that of HMGB1 (compare Fig. 1B, lanes 5 and 6, with Fig. 1C, lane 3). 12/23-regulated cleavage was reconstituted only when the S300 and S600 fractions were combined, producing a marked 12/23 RSS preference for cleavage (Fig. 1C, lane 4). Thus, inhibitory and enhancing components of the regulatory activity found in the WCE could be separated by High S column chromatography. Purification and Characterization of the Cleavage-enhancing and -inhibitory Activities—We purified the cleavage-enhancing activity present in the S600 pool by fractionation as depicted in Supplementary Fig. 1. Mass spectrometry identified the protein as human HMGB2 (data not shown). This protein reacted with anti-HMGB2 antibody on Western blots but migrated faster than native HMGB1 or HMGB2 from WCE (Supplementary Fig. 1C). Its faster electrophoretic mobility and binding characteristics on DNA-cellulose suggested that the form of HMGB2 purified is lacking its acidic carboxyl tail (22Isackson P.J. Beaudoin J. Hermodson M.A. Reeck G.R. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1983; 748: 436-443Crossref PubMed Scopus (10) Google Scholar). Removal of HMGB acidic tail allows for much higher DNA binding and bending characteristics (23Lee K.B. Thomas J.O. J. Mol. Biol. 2000; 304: 135-149Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar). Therefore, cleavage assays were performed to directly compare the HMGB species found in the DNA-cellulose fraction with full-length HMGB1 (Supplementary Fig. 1D). In the presence of the S300 fraction, HMGB1 conferred 12/23 specificity to the RAGs, yet 1.5 μg of HMGB1 were required to compare with the activity found in 10 ng of the DNA-cellulose cleavage enhancing fraction (Supplementary Fig. 1D). We conclude that the cleavage-enhancing activity found in the purified S600 fraction is due to the presence of this fast migrating form of HMGB2 and that full-length HMGB1 could replace the purified activity. We initially attempted to purify the inhibitory activity found in the S300 fraction by column chromatography, but after two subsequent columns the activity was lost (data not shown). Further attempts to purify the regulatory activity failed. As an alternative strategy to identify and characterize the activity present in the S300 fraction, we assayed for proteins known to participate in the DNA repair stage of V(D)J recombination. Western blot analysis demonstrated that the S300 fraction contained Ku70/Ku80, DNA-PKcs, and XRCC4 proteins (Fig. 2A and data not shown). Inhibitory activities of Ku70/Ku80 toward transcription factors have been described (24Ono M. Tucker P.W. Capra J.D. Mol. Immunol. 1996; 33: 787-796Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). To determine whether Ku could be responsible for the cleavage-inhibitory activity of the S300 fraction, we immunodepleted Ku70/Ku80 from the S300 fraction using a monoclonal antibody that exclusively recognizes the native heterodimer (Fig. 2B). Two sequential depletions left only residual Ku proteins in the supernatant, which could not be further depleted (Fig. 2B). An isotype control depletion, using anti-keratin antibodies, retained all Ku70/Ku80 heterodimer in the supernatant (Fig. 2B). The Ku70/Ku80-depleted and control-depleted S300 fractions were then tested in the cleavage assay. Control-depleted S300 fractions were unchanged for activity, inhibiting RAG-mediated cleavage of substrates in the absence of HMGB1 and conferring 12/23 regulation in the presence of HMGB1, demonstrating that the depletion protocol itself does not considerably affect the inhibitory activity (Fig. 2C, lanes 10-13). In contrast, anti-Ku heterodimer depletion removed most of the inhibitory activity from the S300 fraction (Fig. 2C, lanes 2 and 3 versus lanes 6 and 7). When HMGB1 and Ku-depleted S300 were present in the reaction, regulated cleavage activity was lost, with high levels of cleavage of 12/12 and 23/23 substrates (Fig. 2C, lanes 8 and 9). We conclude that Ku70/Ku80 is required for the activity found in the S300 fraction. Reconstitution of the 12/23 Rule with Purified Components—We then addressed whether Ku70/Ku80 is exclusively responsible for the S300 activity. Immunodepletions may have codepleted other factors complexed with Ku70/Ku80, such as DNA-PKcs. We purified Ku70/Ku80 heterodimer and DNA-PKcs in order to reconstitute the reaction (Supplementary Fig. 2). Cleavage assays were performed with combinations of purified RAG1/2, HMGB1, Ku70/80, and DNA-PKcs, whereas protein combinations including the S300 fraction served as controls (Fig. 3). The addition of DNA-PKcs to RAG1/2 or to RAG1/2 with HMGB1 had little effect on the cleavage reaction (Fig. 3). The addition of Ku70/Ku80 to RAG1/2 or to RAG1/2 with HMGB1 inhibited cleavage of all substrates (Fig. 3). This result was identical to the effect of the S300 fraction (Fig. 3, lanes 5 and 6). Although purified Ku heterodimer could inhibit cleavage of the substrates, it could not be used in combination with HMGB1 to regain 12/23 specificity, demonstrating that purified Ku70/Ku80 was not sufficient to replace the activity found in the S300 fraction (Fig. 3, compare control lanes 7 and 8 with lanes 25-28). Thus, neither DNA-PKcs alone nor Ku70/Ku80 alone is sufficient to reconstitute 12/23-regulated cleavage in a reaction mixture containing RAG1/2 and HMGB1. In contrast, when both Ku70/Ku80 and DNA-PKcs were added to a reaction containing RAG1/2 and HMGB1, we observed high levels of cleavage of the 12/23 substrate and significant inhibition of cleavage of 12/12 and 23/23 substrates (Fig. 3, lanes 29-32). This combination of proteins achieved the same effect on RAG-mediated cleavage seen with the combination of S300 and HMGB1 (Fig. 3, lanes 7 and 8). Interestingly, increasing amounts of Ku70/Ku80 within this protein combination did not inhibit the high levels of 12/23-regulated cleavage that were observed (Fig. 3, lanes 29-32). In a reaction containing DNA-PKcs, Ku70/Ku80, and RAG1/2, but lacking HMGB1, regulated cleavage was not observed. Instead, inhibition of cleavage of all substrates was seen (Fig. 3, lane 33). In conclusion, Ku70/80 and DNA-PKcs, when used in combination with RAG1/2 and HMGB1, increase 12/23 specificity by preferentially inhibiting 12/12 and 23/23 cleavage. In Vitro Cleavage Activity and 12/23 Rule of Thioredoxin-RAGs—Since GST dimerization may create nonfunctional RAG complexes that could interfere in our assays, we wanted to investigate whether the protein requirement for the 12/23 rule was independent of the tag used. For this, we generated Trx-core-RAG-expressing vectors. Thioredoxin was chosen, since it has been shown to increase the solubility of the fusion protein upon extraction from cells, similar to GST, yet does not dimerize. We also added the FLAG tag to the N terminus of Trx-core-RAG1 and the HA tag to the N terminus of Trx-core-RAG2. This protein combination was active in in vivo recombination assays (data not shown). Since the FLAG tag was present only in the RAG1 fusion, we took advantage of the FLAG purification system to purify the FLAG-Trx-core-RAG1·HA-Trx-core-RAG2 (Trx-RAGs) complex. As seen in Supplementary Fig. 3A, we successfully purified the Trx-RAG complex from 293T cells. This protein preparation has three major advantages over the GST-RAGs preparation. First, the RAG1-RAG2 complex is enriched, since RAG2 is purified based on its ability to interact with RAG1 and not with the matrix. Second, the possibility of having RAG1-RAG2 complexes through GST dimerization is eliminated; and third, the presence of degradation products was reduced (Supplementary Fig. 3A and data not shown). We next tested the ability of Trx-RAGs to cleave DNA. To increase the sensitivity of the assay as well as to allow detection of the SE product (direct measurement of cleavage at both RSSs), we radiolabeled the linear DNA fragment by PCR as reported (16Eastman Q.M. Leu T.M. Schatz D.G. Nature. 1996; 380: 85-88Crossref PubMed Scopus (208) Google Scholar). This substrate was incubated with either GST-RAGs or Trx-RAGs. Trx-RAGs alone were very inefficient in cleaving DNA, yet when HMGB1 was added to the reaction, Trx-RAGs showed a higher DNA cleavage activity compared with GST-RAGs (Supplementary Fig. 3). Under these conditions, we asked whether Trx-RAGs maintain the 12/23 rule in vitro. For that, we incubated Trx-RAGs with 12/23, 12/12, and 23/23 substrates and quantitated the SE product. As observed in Fig. 4A, at 100 ng of HMGB1, Trx-RAGs cleave efficiently only the 12/23 substrate, although cleavage of 12/12 and 23/23 was also observed. Comparing the levels of SE product, we see a 74- and a 185-fold preference over 12/12 and 23/23 substrates, respectively (Fig. 4A). At higher amounts of HMGB1 (1500 ng), we clearly see an increase of DNA cleavage in all substrates. However, the increase of SE product was higher with 12/12 and 23/23 substrates, resulting in a very significant decrease in 12/23 specificity. The -fold preference over 12/12 and 23/23 substrates was 15 and 26, reflecting a decrease of 5 and 7 times in 12/23 regulation, respectively (Fig. 4A). GST-RAGs were less efficient in maintaining the 12/23 rule in the presence of 100 ng of HMGB1, with a -fold preference over 12/12 and 23/23 of 5.1 and 8.8, respectively. However, 12/23 specificity was not significantly affected by increasing the HMGB1 concentration (Fig. 4A). Overall, Trx-RAGs show higher activity in cleavage and 12/23 regulation when they

Chimeras of Hxt2 and Hxt1, high affinity and low affinity glucose transporters, respectively, of Saccharomyces cerevisiae, were previously constructed by random replacement of each of the 12 transmembrane segments (TMs) of Hxt2 with the corresponding region of Hxt1. Characterization of these chimeras revealed that at least TMs 1, 5, 7, and 8 of Hxt2 are required for high affinity transport activity. To determine which amino acid residues in these TMs are important for high affinity glucose transport, we systematically shuffled all of the 20 residues in these regions that differ between Hxt2 and Hxt1. Analysis of 60 independent mutant strains identified as expressing high affinity and high capacity glucose transport activity by selection on glucose-limited agar plates revealed that Leu-201 in TM5 of Hxt2 is most important for such activity and that either Cys-195 or Phe-198 is also required for maximal activity.

Transfer of conjugative plasmids between bacteria requires the activity of relaxases or mobilization proteins. These proteins nick the plasmid in a site- and strand-specific manner prior to transfer of the cut strand from donor to recipient. TraI36, the relaxase domain of TraI from plasmid F factor, binds a single-stranded DNA (ssDNA) oligonucleotide containing an F factor sequence with high affinity and sequence specificity. To better understand the energetics of this interaction, we examined the temperature, salt, and pH dependence of TraI36 recognition. Binding is entropically driven below 25 °C and enthalpically driven at higher temperatures. van't Hoff analysis yields an estimated ΔCP0 of binding (–3300 cal mol–1 K–1) that is larger and more negative than that observed for most double-stranded DNA (dsDNA)-binding proteins. Based on analyses of circular dichroism data and the crystal structure of the unliganded protein, we attribute the ΔCP0 to both burial of hydrophobic surface area and coupled folding and binding of the protein. The salt dependence of the binding indicates that several ssDNA phosphates are buried in the complex, and the pH dependence of the binding suggests that some of these ssDNA phosphates form ionic interactions with basic residues of the protein. Although data are available for relatively few sequence-specific ssDNA-binding proteins, sufficient differences exist between TraI36 and other proteins to indicate that, like dsDNA-binding proteins, ssDNA-binding proteins use different motifs and combinations of forces to achieve specific recognition. The salt dependence of the binding indicates that several ssDNA phosphates are buried in the complex, and the pH dependence of the binding suggests that some of these ssDNA phosphates form ionic interactions with basic residues of the protein. Although data are available for relatively few sequence-specific ssDNA-binding proteins, sufficient differences exist between TraI36 and other proteins to indicate that, like dsDNA-binding proteins, ssDNA-binding proteins use different motifs and combinations of forces to achieve specific recognition. Essential genetic functions including transcription, replication, cleavage, methylation, and recombination rely on the ability of proteins to recognize specific DNA sequences among an enormous population of competing binding sites. To understand the underlying elements of this sequence-specific binding, researchers have undertaken extensive studies of double-stranded DNA (dsDNA) 1The abbreviations used are: dsDNA, double-stranded DNA; ssDNA, single-stranded DNA; TAMRA, carboxytetramethylrhodamine; CAPS, 3-(cyclohexylamino)propanesulfonic acid; bis-tris propane, 1,3-bis[tris-(hydroxymethyl)methylamino]propane.-binding proteins (reviewed in Refs. 1Hard T. Lundback T. Biophys. Chem. 1996; 62: 121-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 2Garvie C.W. Wolberger C. Mol. Cell. 2001; 8: 937-946Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar, 3Jen-Jacobson L. Engler L.E. Jacobson L.A. Structure Fold Des. 2000; 8: 1015-1023Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (227) Google Scholar). These studies have shown that nature employs a variety of protein structural elements to recognize DNA, including β-sheets, α-helices, and loops. Protein-DNA complexes are stabilized in myriad ways, including hydrophobic, van der Waals, and ionic interactions. Binding specificity, however, is frequently mediated through formation of patterns of hydrogen bonding interactions between the protein and DNA bases in the major groove (2Garvie C.W. Wolberger C. Mol. Cell. 2001; 8: 937-946Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar). Overall, these studies indicate that sequence-specific interactions between protein and dsDNA are fashioned from a broad base of structures and binding modes. In contrast, relatively few studies have examined the sequence-specific interaction between proteins and single-stranded DNA (ssDNA). The available structures of sequence-specific ssDNA-binding proteins involved in various aspects of DNA metabolism suggest that ssDNA binding is also accomplished using a variety of protein folds including an oligonucleotide/oligosaccharide binding fold and modified RNA recognition motifs (4Mitton-Fry R.M. More detailed information on binding by these proteins through mutagenesis and biophysical characterization is now becoming available. F factor TraI plays an integral role in the process of F bacterial conjugation, cleaving and unwinding a single strand of the plasmid prior to transfer. The 36-kDa relaxase domain of F factor TraI (TraI36) binds its origin of transfer binding site oligonucleotide with a subnanomolar dissociation constant and with extreme sequence specificity (18Stern J.C. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 11586-11595Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). In an effort to better understand the molecular basis of the binding of TraI36 to ssDNA, we examined the effects of changing temperature, pH, and ionic strength on the binding affinity. Protein and Oligonucleotides—The 22-base 3′-TAMRA-labeled oligonucleotide F-TAM (5′-TTTGCGTGGGGTGTGGTGCTTT-3′) containing the TraI origin of transfer binding site (19Sherman J.A. Matson S.W. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 26220-26226Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) was synthesized by Integrated DNA Technologies and purified as described (18Stern J.C. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 11586-11595Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). TraI36, a 36-kDa N-terminal domain of F Factor TraI possessing relaxase activity, was expressed and purified as described (20Street L.M. Harley M.J. Stern J.C. Larkin C. Williams S.L. Miller D.L. Dohm J.A. Rodgers M.E. Schildbach J.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2003; 1646: 86-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Affinity Measurements—Affinity of TraI36 for the single-stranded F-TAM oligonucleotide was measured by following changes in fluorescence intensity and anisotropy upon protein titration as described (18Stern J.C. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 11586-11595Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) except the standard buffer used was 20 mm bis-tris propane (pH 7.5), 100 mm NaCl, and 0.1 mm EDTA. For assessing salt dependence of binding, a solution of 20 mm bis-tris propane (pH 7.5) and 0.1 mm EDTA was supplemented with NaCl, NaBr, KCl, or KBr in concentrations ranging from 100 to 500 mm. To determine the relationship between pH and affinity, a solution of 100 mm NaCl and 0.1 mm EDTA was buffered at the desired pH using 20 mm bis-tris propane (pH 9.5–6.5), 20 mm sodium cacodylate (pH 5.5–6.5), or 20 mm CAPS (pH 9.7–11.0). Salt and pH dependence measurements were conducted at 25 °C. Salt release stoichiometry was calculated as follows. SKobs≡δlnKobs/δln[MX](Eq. 1) The confidence intervals for the SKobs values were calculated from the standard error of the linear regression fit and the t distribution as described (21Rosner B. Fundamentals of Biostatistics. 4th Ed. Duxbury Press, Belmont, CA1995: 462-465Google Scholar). van't Hoff Analysis—Affinity titrations were performed at temperatures from 7 to 35 °C in the standard buffer. The pH of the buffer in this range of temperatures should vary between 8.1 and 7.2. Binding affinity does not differ significantly over this pH range. Results were analyzed as described (22Ackroyd P.C. Cleary J. Glick G.D. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 2911-2922Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). The data were plotted as ln Ka (the equilibrium affinity constant) versus 1/T and fitted with the equation, lnKobs=ΔCP0/R[TH/T−ln(TS/T)−1](Eq. 2) where ΔCP0 is the heat capacity change R is the gas constant, TH is the temperature at which ΔH0 is zero, and TS is the temperature at which ΔS0 is zero. Kaleidagraph 3.5 (Synergy Software) was used to fit models to the data. Circular Dichroism Measurements—Circular dichroism (CD) wavelength spectra of 10 μm TraI36 in 0.1 mm EDTA, 100 mm NaCl, and 20 mm CAPS at either pH 9.7 or pH 10.5 were collected on an AVIV 62DS CD spectrometer using a 0.1-cm path length cuvette. The signal was averaged for 5 s at each 1-nm interval. Thermal denaturation of these samples was performed using the same instrument and cuvette with unfolding followed by loss of negative ellipticity at 220 nm. The temperature was varied from 25 to 75 °C in 1 °C steps, and the CD signal was averaged for 30 s following a 1-min equilibration at each temperature step. The relaxase domain of F factor TraI (TraI36) binds to ssDNA with a high degree of sequence specificity. Single base changes in the single-stranded binding site oligonucleotide can reduce TraI36 affinities by up to 8000-fold (18Stern J.C. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 11586-11595Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). To our knowledge, only the telomere-binding protein Pot1 of Schizosaccharomyces pombe approaches this level of sequence-specific recognition of ssDNA (23Lei M. Baumann P. Cech T.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 14560-14568Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Temperature Dependence of Binding—The crystal structure of the uncomplexed TraI36 protein (13Datta S. Larkin C. Schildbach J.F. Structure. 2003; 11: 1369-1379Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar) and the sequence specificity of TraI36 for its ssDNA binding site (18Stern J.C. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 11586-11595Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) strongly suggest that the specific ssDNA recognition of this protein requires a high degree of surface complementarity between the protein and DNA bases. To better define the energetics of binding, affinity titrations were performed between 5 and 35 °C to estimate the enthalpic and entropic contributions to binding. The ln Ka was plotted versus 1/T (K) for van't Hoff analysis (Fig. 1). Highest affinity binding occurs at ∼25 °C. Above this temperature, binding is enthalpically driven, whereas binding is entropically driven at lower temperatures. The deviation of the plotted data from linearity reflects a large negative ΔCP0 of binding (–3.3 kcal mol–1 K–1), which is commonly seen among sequence-specific interactions of proteins with dsDNA (1Hard T. Lundback T. Biophys. Chem. 1996; 62: 121-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar). A large negative ΔCP0 of binding might result from the removal of solvent-accessible surface areas and from conformational changes upon binding (1Hard T. Lundback T. Biophys. Chem. 1996; 62: 121-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 24Ha J.H. Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 209: 801-816Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar). Because the binding showed temperature dependence, with affinity falling at temperatures greater than 25 °C, we investigated whether results might be influenced by conformational changes in the protein and/or oligonucleotide at the higher temperatures. The TraI36 protein does not undergo significant structural rearrangements at the temperatures used in the van't Hoff analysis. Thermal denaturations monitored by circular dichroism (CD) indicate that TraI36 maintains a baseline signal through 45 °C and undergoes a highly cooperative unfolding transition with a Tm of ∼55 °C (20Street L.M. Harley M.J. Stern J.C. Larkin C. Williams S.L. Miller D.L. Dohm J.A. Rodgers M.E. Schildbach J.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2003; 1646: 86-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). Intrinsic tryptophan fluorescence emission spectra of TraI36 do not change between 5 and 35 °C (not shown), also suggesting that TraI36 undergoes no large scale structural changes over the temperature range used in the binding measurements. Other experiments provide no evidence for temperature-induced changes in oligonucleotide structure. First, because optical properties of DNA bases can change with changing environments, we collected absorbance spectra of F-TAM at different temperatures over the range from 5 to 35 °C. The spectra did not change when the temperatures changed, meaning that there were no observable differences in the environment of the bases, including intra- and intermolecular interactions (data not shown). Second, emission spectra of the F-TAM oligonucleotide using excitation wavelengths of 520 and 540 nm were taken at 5 and 35 °C. The normalized spectra were identical, providing no evidence of heterogeneity in the solutions at either temperature and no evidence of changes to the solution because of temperature (data not shown). Third, TraI36 binds with similar affinity to the F-TAM oligonucleotide and a smaller TAMRA-labeled oligonucleotide that contains the 5′ 17 bases of F-TAM (F-TAM17), both at 25 (18Stern J.C. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 11586-11595Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar) and 35 °C (not shown). The similarity in the temperature dependence of binding for these two oligonucleotides suggests that at least the 5 bases at the 3′-end of F-TAM do not participate in intra- or intermolecular interactions that affect binding over this temperature range. The large negative ΔCP0 for TraI36 binding its specific site (–3.3 kcal mol–1 K–1) is greater than the values observed for sequence-specific binding of many proteins to duplex DNA (24Ha J.H. Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 209: 801-816Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar, 25Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. Science. 1994; 263: 777-784Crossref PubMed Scopus (1373) Google Scholar, 26Poon G.M. Gross P. Macgregor Jr., R.B. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 2361-2371Crossref PubMed Scopus (14) Google Scholar). Analysis of the site-specific dsDNA binding of proteins indicates that much of the ΔCP0 observed stems from the hydrophobic effect, specifically the burial of nonpolar surfaces upon binding (1Hard T. Lundback T. Biophys. Chem. 1996; 62: 121-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 24Ha J.H. Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 209: 801-816Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar, 25Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. Science. 1994; 263: 777-784Crossref PubMed Scopus (1373) Google Scholar, 27Gallagher K. Sharp K. Biophys. J. 1998; 75: 769-776Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). We expect that considerable nonpolar surface is buried upon binding given the extensive region (∼11 bases) of ssDNA specifically recognized by TraI36 (18Stern J.C. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 11586-11595Crossref PubMed Scopus (41) Google Scholar). In addition, the binding cleft of TraI36 contains numerous small, nonaromatic hydrophobic amino acids and a number of pits large enough to accommodate DNA bases in a knob-into-hole fashion, both of which are consistent with burial of considerable hydrophobic surface area upon binding. Indeed, if the observed ΔCP0 were due entirely to burial of hydrophobic surfaces upon binding, the entropic contribution to binding could be estimated (25Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. Science. 1994; 263: 777-784Crossref PubMed Scopus (1373) Google Scholar) according to Equation 3. ΔSHE0(T)=1.35ΔCp0 ln(T/386)(Eq. 3) At 301 K, TS, or the temperature at which the total entropic contribution to binding is zero, is 1100 entropic units (cal K–1 mol–1), which translates into a ΔG =–330 kcal mol–1. Because there probably are factors other than burial of hydrophobic surface area contributing to ΔCP0 (discussed below), this estimate of the entropic contribution to binding represents an upper limit. Directly measuring the surface area buried upon binding will require determination of the structure of the TraI36-ssDNA complex, which we are actively pursuing. By definition, at TS the entropic contribution to binding is offset by other entropic terms. The contributions of two of these terms, the reduction in translational and rotational entropy upon forming the complex and the polyelectrolyte effect, are thought to be small relative to the contributions from the hydrophobic effect (25Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. Science. 1994; 263: 777-784Crossref PubMed Scopus (1373) Google Scholar, 27Gallagher K. Sharp K. Biophys. J. 1998; 75: 769-776Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (103) Google Scholar). The remaining difference between the terms is often attributed to coupled folding and binding (25Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. Science. 1994; 263: 777-784Crossref PubMed Scopus (1373) Google Scholar). CD data provide evidence that folding of TraI36 and DNA does occur upon binding. Summed CD spectra of uncomplexed TraI36 and a 22-base unlabeled single-stranded oligonucleotide were compared with the CD spectra of an equimolar solution of protein and oligonucleotide (20Street L.M. Harley M.J. Stern J.C. Larkin C. Williams S.L. Miller D.L. Dohm J.A. Rodgers M.E. Schildbach J.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2003; 1646: 86-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar). The negative ellipticity at 222 nm is increased, indicating formation or stabilization of α-helical structures. The peak of the positive ellipticity between 270 and 290 nm, which is attributable to the oligonucleotide, increases in magnitude and shifts to a lower wavelength, suggesting that in the complex the oligonucleotide is adopting a particular conformation or limited ensemble of conformations. The crystal structure of the uncomplexed TraI36 protein has two regions in which the electron density was insufficient to trace, presumably because the regions are poorly ordered (13Datta S. Larkin C. Schildbach J.F. Structure. 2003; 11: 1369-1379Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar). One of these regions (amino acids 236–267) is located near the binding cleft, and it is feasible that this segment becomes ordered as the protein binds to ssDNA. It is therefore plausible that the large negative ΔCP0 observed for the sequence-specific binding of TraI36 to ssDNA has substantial contributions not only from burial of hydrophobic surface area but also from coupled folding and binding. One specific way in which the oligonucleotide may contribute to the observed ΔCP0 of the interaction is through unstacking of bases upon binding. The more negative ΔCP0 observed when Escherichia coli single-stranded binding protein binds to single-stranded oligodeoxyadenylates compared with when binding oligodeoxypyrimidines was attributed to unstacking of adenines coupled with binding of the protein (28Kozlov A.G. Lohman T.M. Biochemistry. 1999; 38: 7388-7397Crossref PubMed Scopus (68) Google Scholar). The F-TAM oligonucleotide has a high guanine content, and it is likely that the bases are stacked to some degree when the oligonucleotide is in the unbound state. The base composition of a ssDNA oligonucleotide, attributed at least in part to base stacking, has been shown to affect its solution characteristics, including flexibility (29Goddard N.L. Bonnet G. Krichevsky O. Libchaber A. Phys. Rev. Lett. 2000; 85: 2400-2403Crossref PubMed Scopus (260) Google Scholar). Salt and pH Dependence of Binding—Electrostatic interactions, especially between amino acid side chains of basic residues and the DNA phosphate backbone, contribute frequently to DNA binding. Binding affinity is therefore often influenced by salt concentration. The van't Hoff analysis indicates that the binding energy has a significant enthalpic contribution and that the binding is enthalpically driven above 25 °C. To further investigate the electrostatic contribution to the TraI36-DNA interaction, we assessed the effects of several salts on TraI36 affinity for ssDNA. The affinity of TraI36 for the oligonucleotide decreases as salt concentrations increase. In Fig. 2, the ln Ka of TraI36 is plotted versus the ln of salt concentration for NaCl, NaBr, KCl, and KBr. As has been observed for dsDNA-binding proteins (24Ha J.H. Spolar R.S. Record Jr., M.T. J. Mol. Biol. 1989; 209: 801-816Crossref PubMed Scopus (393) Google Scholar, 30Barkley M.D. Lewis P.A. Sullivan G.E. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 3842-3851Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar) the identity of the anion has a greater impact than the cation on the affinity of TraI36 for ssDNA with higher affinities in the presence of Cl– than Br–. For example, the affinity of TraI36 is consistently higher at a given concentration of NaCl than at the same concentration of NaBr, whereas the affinities for NaCl and KCl are similar. Similarly, as for dsDNA-binding proteins, the affinity of TraI36 for ssDNA in solutions with acetate as an anion is higher than for those with Cl– or Br– (not shown). The salt dependence of binding can reflect conformational changes in the protein upon binding, ion release from the DNA upon binding (polyelectrolyte effect), and ion pairing in the complex. As described previously, there is evidence of conformational changes for both protein and DNA upon binding, and these could contribute to the apparent salt dependence of binding. Regarding the polyelectrolyte effect, the slope of the linear fits to the data, SKobs, is often related to the stoichiometry of salt release for the binding event. SKobs values for NaCl (–4.16) and KCl (–4.26) are smaller than the values for NaBr (–5.03) and KBr (–5.04). Although the salt dependence of binding is usually dominated by the effect of cation release, the different values for the Cl– and Br– salts may reflect a small effect because of anion release upon binding. The confidence limits of the slopes for all data sets overlap at the 90% level, however, limiting the conclusions that we can draw from the data. If we assume that there is only a minor influence of anion release on binding, then the SKobs values can be interpreted in terms of the number of cations released upon binding. Relating the SKobs values to the product of 0.7 and the number of cations released (22Ackroyd P.C. Cleary J. Glick G.D. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 2911-2922Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar) yields an estimate of 6 (NaCl, KCl) or 7 (NaBr, KBr) cations released from the phosphates upon binding. This estimate, however, assumes a constant concentration of cations along the length of DNA and may be influenced by strong end effects (31Olmsted M.C. Anderson C.F. Record Jr., M.T. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 7766-7770Crossref PubMed Scopus (116) Google Scholar). Even if this is an overestimate of the number of cations released upon binding, it strongly suggests that a number of ssDNA phosphates are buried in the TraI36-ssDNA complex. The TraI36 SKobs values and the estimated number of cations released by TraI36 binding are in the same range as many of those reported for dsDNA-binding proteins, including EcoRI (SKobs =–8; cations released = 7) (32Sidorova N.Y. Rau D.C. J. Mol. Biol. 2001; 310: 801-816Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar) and lac repressor (cations released = 7.5–9.3) (30Barkley M.D. Lewis P.A. Sullivan G.E. Biochemistry. 1981; 20: 3842-3851Crossref PubMed Scopus (77) Google Scholar). The SKobs values are similar to the results for the KCl dependence of the binding of the ssDNA-binding domain of Saccharomyces cerevisiae protein Cdc13 (33Anderson E.M. Halsey W.A. Wuttke D.S. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 3751-3758Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). In contrast, the Oxytrichia nova telomere end-binding protein α subunit reportedly shows only a 2-fold lower affinity for its target ssDNA sequence in 400 mm compared with 100 mm NaCl (34Classen S. Lyons D. Cech T.R. Schultz S.C. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 9269-9277Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). The Pot1 protein of S. pombe also shows only a minor salt dependence of binding consistent with formation of a single ion pair between protein and ssDNA (23Lei M. Baumann P. Cech T.R. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 14560-14568Crossref PubMed Scopus (71) Google Scholar). Whereas TraI36 interacts with phosphate groups in its ssDNA binding site, there are relatively few basic amino acids within the TraI36 binding site (20Street L.M. Harley M.J. Stern J.C. Larkin C. Williams S.L. Miller D.L. Dohm J.A. Rodgers M.E. Schildbach J.F. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 2003; 1646: 86-99Crossref PubMed Scopus (38) Google Scholar), suggesting that few ion pairs may form between the phosphates and the protein side chains. Binding affinities were measured from pH 5.5 to 10.5 (sodium cacodylate buffer was used from pH 5.5 to 7.5, bis-tris propane buffer from pH 6.5 to 9.5, and CAPS buffer from pH 9.7 to 10.5) (Fig. 3). Over the pH range from 5.5 to 9.7, the binding appears relatively independent of pH. The binding affinity drops significantly at pH 10.5, with the Kd value rising 30-fold relative to that at pH 9.7. The affinity continues to fall as the pH increases, with no binding observed at pH 11 at 900 nm TraI36 (not shown). The reduced affinity at pH 10.5 relative to pH 9.7 does not appear to be because of a destabilization of the protein at the higher pH. TraI36 has comparable CD spectra at the two pH values (not shown). Furthermore, although the apparent Tm of TraI36 is lower at pH 10.5 (∼47 °C) than at pH 9.7 (∼51 °C), the binding data were collected at 25 °C, a temperature well below the start of the unfolding transition (not shown). The correlation of rising pH and the presumable deprotonation of basic residues in the binding site suggests that the cation release upon binding is accompanied by formation of salt bridges between some of the phosphates and some of the protein side chains. Although the fluorescence intensity of the TAMRA dye of the F-TAM oligonucleotide increases upon TraI36 binding at all pH values tested, at pH 10.5 the fluorescence anisotropy drops upon binding whereas at all other pH values tested the anisotropy increases upon binding (Fig. 4). This suggests that some aspect of the environment of the TAMRA dye and its resulting behavior is altered at the higher pH. Consistent with these observations, substituting Arg-150 in TraI36 with an Ala reduces affinity for ssDNA by ∼30-fold and also affects the anisotropic characteristics of the fluorophore (35Harley M.J. Toptygin D. Troxler T. Schildbach J.F. Biochemistry. 2002; 41: 6460-6468Crossref PubMed Scopus (19) Google Scholar). A variety of factors may contribute to the sequence-specific binding of a protein to a DNA sequence: hydrogen bonding, van der Waals interactions, base stacking, the polyelectrolyte effect of DNA, and dehydration at the complex interface (1Hard T. Lundback T. Biophys. Chem. 1996; 62: 121-139Crossref PubMed Scopus (48) Google Scholar, 2Garvie C.W. Wolberger C. Mol. Cell. 2001; 8: 937-946Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (280) Google Scholar, 3Jen-Jacobson L. Engler L.E. Jacobson L.A. Structure Fold Des. 2000; 8: 1015-1023Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF Scopus (227) Google Scholar, 22Ackroyd P.C. Cleary J. Glick G.D. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 2911-2922Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar). Thermodynamic studies allow for the elucidation of the different factors involved in a binding event. However, the vast majority of thermodynamic studies of sequence-specific DNA binding have been done on proteins that recognize dsDNA. Very few studies have been done on sequence-specific ssDNA binders. Perhaps the most thorough study of the energetics of a protein binding to ssDNA sequence specifically was actually performed on an anti-ssDNA lupus antibody (22Ackroyd P.C. Cleary J. Glick G.D. Biochemistry. 2001; 40: 2911-2922Crossref PubMed Scopus (27) Google Scholar), rather than on a protein involved in DNA metabolism. Here we show that TraI36 exhibits many characteristics of dsDNA-binding proteins, including a large negative ΔCP0, an involvement of electrostatics and a corresponding salt dependence of binding, and a coupling of binding with protein folding. A quantitatively similar involvement of electrostatics has also been demonstrated for the binding of the ssDNA-binding domain of S. cerevisiae Cdc13, although a mutagenesis study indicates that the hydrophobic and especially aromatic side chains of this protein make greater energetic contributions to binding than the charged side chains (33Anderson E.M. Halsey W.A. Wuttke D.S. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 3751-3758Crossref PubMed Scopus (49) Google Scholar). An analysis of the binding of the α subunit of O. nova telomere end-binding protein also suggests that the binding specificity of this protein, like that of Cdc13, correlates not only with the stacking of the DNA bases, aromatic side chains, and other bases but also with the formation of a specific pattern of hydrogen bonding (34Classen S. Lyons D. Cech T.R. Schultz S.C. Biochemistry. 2003; 42: 9269-9277Crossref PubMed Scopus (17) Google Scholar). The specificity of the Pot1 telomere-binding protein is achieved through both intramolecular base stacking and hydrogen bonding interactions in the bound ssDNA as well as intermolecular hydrogen bonding and stacking interactions between amino acid side chains and DNA bases (16Lei M. Podell E.R. Baumann P. Cech T.R. Nature. 2003; 426: 198-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (162) Google Scholar). In contrast, TraI36 has few aromatic residues within its binding cleft, meaning that few if any stacking interactions occur between the protein and DNA bases and strongly suggesting that the details of the binding by these proteins differ in significant ways. Whereas the same forces that contribute to sequence specificity of binding to dsDNA contribute to the binding of TraI36 to ssDNA, the larger estimated negative ΔCP0 observed for TraI36 than has been observed for most dsDNA-binding proteins may reflect differences in the form of DNA bound. Burial of hydrophobic surface area and unstacking of DNA bases may both contribute to the large negative ΔCP0. The ssDNA bound by TraI36, because it is not involved in base pairing, likely has more surface area available per base than a similar length of dsDNA. Similarly, the lack of base pairing and the resulting increased flexibility of the ssDNA suggest that the bases of ssDNA are more likely than those of dsDNA to adopt unstacked, non-B-like conformations when interacting with a protein to achieve binding specificity. The unstacked bases and their interactions with each other and with the protein seen in the crystal structures of the O. nova telomere end-binding protein bound to ssDNA strongly suggest that the flexibility of ssDNA contributes to the ssDNA recognition by this protein (5Horvath M.P. Because nearly all structure/function studies on Na+/K+-ATPase have been done on enzymes prepared in the presence of SDS, we have studied previously unrecognized consequences of SDS interaction with the enzyme. When the purified membrane-bound kidney enzyme was solubilized with SDS or TDS concentrations just sufficient to cause complete solubilization, but not at concentrations severalfold higher, the enzyme retained quaternary structure, exhibiting α,α-, α,β-, β,β-, and α,γ-associations as detected by chemical cross-linking. The presence of solubilized oligomers was confirmed by sucrose density gradient centrifugation. This solubilized enzyme had no ATPase activity and was not phosphorylated by ATP, but it retained the ability to occlude Rb+ and Na+. This, and comparison of cross-linking patterns obtained with different reagents, suggested that the transmembrane domains of the enzyme are more resistant to SDS-induced unfolding than its other domains. These findings (a) indicate that the partially unfolded oligomer(s) retaining partial function is the intermediate in the SDS-induced denaturation of the native membrane enzyme having the minimum oligomeric structure of (α,β,γ)2 and (b) suggest potential functions for Na+/K+-ATPase with intrinsically unfolded domains. Mixtures of solubilized/partially unfolded enzyme and membrane-bound enzyme exhibited cross-linking patterns and Na+ occlusion capacities different from those of either enzyme species, suggesting that the two interact. Formation of the partially unfolded enzyme during standard purification procedure for the preparation of the membrane-bound enzyme was shown, indicating that it is necessary to ensure the separation of the partially unfolded enzyme from the membrane-bound enzyme to avoid the distortion of the properties of the latter.
